awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Modular Hybrid Green Infrastructure Technology for Addressing Stormwater Challenges
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is that it provides a cost-effective, low-impact hybrid 'green' approach for addressing stormwater runoff, one of the leading causes of impairment to our nation's waters. These runoff problems are expected to be exacerbated, particularly in urban areas, as a result of the coupled impacts of future population growth-driven land use and cover changes and storm events associated with projected climate change. Recognition of these threats to our water resources, together with the increasing costs of conventional municipal water treatment, has led to interest in green infrastructure approaches for stormwater management.  However, in their current design, many of these green infrastructure systems are passive: their effectiveness for intercepting water and removing pollutants is highly variable.  The technology described here will provide stormwater engineers, developers, city managers, and homeowners with important design criteria that will maximize green infrastructure performance and functionality.  The commercialization of this hybrid green technology is therefore key for making it widely accessible to potential end-users to address both present and future stormwater/water resource challenges.

This I-Corps project will assess the market potential and commercialization feasibility of a modular, hybrid stormwater management technology that augments green infrastructure both to maximize pollutant removal efficiency and allow for water storage.  The modular hybrid green infrastructure (MHGI) is a sealed system with a specialized pipe and valve assembly that allows for both the control of water retention times as well as the location of the subsurface water table height, so that intercepted stormwater can be held within the soil matrix at a depth to maximize aerobic/anaerobic conditions that promote bioremediation via plant and microbial processing. Stormwater storage times can be controlled and the system can be made operational to adjust for changes in historical or projected runoff volumes. The intercepted water can also be stored within the system, pending removal by evapotranspiration, or for reuse purposes such as irrigation.  Preliminary alpha testing of this technology demonstrated significant and consistent nitrogen and phosphorus removal efficiencies with 88% nitrate and 100% phosphate removal observed for urban runoff, 95% total nitrogen and 81% phosphate removal observed for septic effluent, and 50% nitrate, 71% ammonium, and 55% removal observed for agricultural runoff.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this I-Corps award was to assess the market potential and commercialization feasibility of a modular, hybrid stormwater management technology (ecoWEIRTM, patented) that actively controls green infrastructure performance and funtionality.  ecoWEIR technology integrates grey and ‘green’ infrastructure into one modular sealed system that can control water retention times and soil conditions, maximize pollutant removal, and allow for water storage and re-use. It functions similarly to other more conventional decentralized water management approaches such as stormwater vaults and gravel beds by detaining water from entering sewers. However, with the specialized ecoWEIR pipe and valve assembly, storage times can be controlled and the system can adjust for changes in historical or projected runoff volumes (i.e. dryer conditions vs. storm events). ecoWEIR allows for the controlled release of infiltrated stormwater into either the sewer system or the soil below for groundwater recharge.  The specialized piped and valve assembly also enhances pollutant removal efficiencies by holding intercepted stormwater within the soil matrix at a depth that enhances aerobic/anaerobic redox conditions, which promotes nitrogen and phosphorus removal via plant and microbial processing.

 

Our I-Corps team conducted 104 interviews with potential customers and customer segments in major urban areas across the US over the 6-week training period. We targeted customers who would likely be early adopters our technology. Those interviewed included developers, architects, engineers, municipal employees (regulators, managers, policy makers), landscape architects, homeowners, potential competitors, and environmental advocates/community organizers. Over the course of these interviews, we learned that since water issues vary significantly from region to region and even within a geographic area the value proposition for our technology was highly dependent on geographic region and hence regulatory pressures. Most importantly though, we identified a set of value propositions for ecoWEIR technology that were common to all geographic locations: a) it meets stormwater regulation requirements and be a tested and approved best management approach, b) it allows for system optimization aligned with geographic location and needs (i.e. water storage and controlled release, water treatment, and/or water reuse) and its performance can be controlled and monitored, c) its implementation allows for design flexibility to meet space size and usage requirements and restrictions, d) it is cost effective both for up-front installation and long-term maintenance, and finally e) its use frees up space and provides enhanced property aesthetics.

 

At the end of the training, our team determined that we would move toward commercialization of ecoWEIR technology.  We identified specific first steps for garnering funding to establish test bed sites to get the technology certified as a best management practice so that our company will be better positioned to enter the market place and grow as a start­up. The I-Corps training was rigorous and required focus and attention for keying in on critical customer needs. During the six short weeks the training provided us with a better understanding of opportunities and obstacles for decentralized stormwater management solutions such as ecoWEIR technology in urban areas.  It allowed our team to significantly expand our network and establish connections with future potential customers and partners and also, importantly, allowed for team members to break down expertise-specific communication barriers and develop tools for communicating between academia, the private sector, and municipalities.  Collectively, all of these outcomes helped to create a path forward for growing a viable business. 

 

Water resource sustainability is widely perceived to be one of the ultimate challenges for the 21st Century with urban stormwater runoff identified as one of the leading causes of impairment to our nation’s waters.  These runoff problems are expected to get worse, particularly in urban areas, as a result of the coupled impacts of future population growth-driven land use and cover changes and projected climate change associated storm events.  Recognition of these threats to our water resources together with the increasing costs of conventional municipal water treatment has led to interest in the use of green infrastructure approaches for stormwater management.  Unfortunately, however, in their current design many of these green infrastructure systems are passive, making their effectiveness for intercepting water and removing pollutants variable.  The commercialization of ecoWEIR technology will provide stormwater engineers, developers, city managers, and homeowners with important design criteria that will allow for the maximization of green infrastructure performance and functionality. It will lead toward more rigorous adoption of decentralized green infrastructure solutions for urban water management and hence the ultimate protection of water resources. The ‘greening of our cities’ with decentralized stormwater technology like ecoWEIR will further provide other important ancillary benefits for urban areas such as offsetting heat island effects, creating more biodiversity and enhancing overall livability of urban spaces.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2017
Modified by: Jennifer Cherrier
